ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We began with recorded lectures that we watched ahead of a help session during "class time", but about half way through the semester we switched to live lectures.
In the beginning of the semester we did recorded lectures, but then Professor Bennett switched to live lecture.

Until about mid-term, this course was taught as a flipped classroom, meaning that we had pre-recorded lectures to watch before class and class time was given over to a quick recap of the recordings and answers to conceptual questions. I found this format easier to work within and better for my learning style.
The plenitude of office hours were also quite helpful.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to approximate the solution of various numerical questions, as well as to think critically about the behavior of such algorithms and what edge cases would throw them off.
I learned so much from this course about function approximation, numerical methods for integration, and more. I also learned Matlab, because I didn't know it before this course.
Root finding for nonlinear equations, linear system solving (direct and iterative methods), solving systems of nonlinear equations, function and integration approximation

I learned how to apply various root-finding methods and what their various pros and cons were, how to approximately solve linear systems of equations through various methods and what those methods pros and cons were (depending on the linear system and method, these approximations could be pretty darn exact; other times not so much), how to determine (usually) fairly exact approximations to the eigenvalues of a matrix using various methods and what those methods pros and cons were, and how to produce interpolating functions and approximate integrals over a finite set of observations.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strength of this course is whole heartedly found in the professor. Beth is the best teacher I have ever had at Yale. She takes the time to make sure that every student understands everything and she is so so prepared that the only thing the students need to worry about is the material. She has very high expectations of her students, but she gives them all the support necessary for us to reach them.
An excellent course. Professor Bennett teaches really clearly, we cover a wide range of subject matter but you definitely actually get to learn it thoroughly.

Even with the COVID-induced change in some course procedures, this is a very well-taught and well-organized course. Lectures, exams, and problem sets are very well-written, and the Professors attention to detail makes all the non-material parts of the course very easy. (This attention to detail also almost certainly helps make learning the material easier.)
I preferred the initial flipped format for this course, but I understand why it seemed necessary to switch to a live-lecture format.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really appreciated having more exams of less weight. It made it impossible to fall too far behind and kept you really accountable. The tech issues and tablet were sub-par though and often hindered the amount of material we could get through by the end of class.

I think I preferred the recorded lectures because you could watch at your own pace, but the live lectures were also good. I loved that Professor Bennett and Khoi were available for office hours over Zoom so often, it was super helpful. I also appreciated our class's Slack channel to be able to ask questions remotely.
I found that the flipped classroom was a helpful format compared to the live lectures used by my past classes in this subject area.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would deeply recommend this class to other math majors looking for a fun course, but it's completely out of reach for non-math majors.
YES!!! Such a good class, one of the best-organized STEM classes I've taken at Yale. Professor Bennett is awesome! You will learn so much.

Yes. Beth Anne Bennett is a great lecturer, and the course material is really great.

If you're a math major looking to explore some more applied topics, this course is a fine choice.

I would absolutely recommend this course to students who are interested but on the fence.
Dr. Bennett is a treasure of the applied sciences faculty. Her course presents interesting concepts that are important/applicable across a LOT of disciplines, and teaches them well. Everything is well-written, thoroughly thought through, and well-organized, and problem sets provide a lot of good practice in using numerical methods to write programs that solve simpler (but not necessarily less interesting) math problems.
